learning_outcomes.description: Describe several strategies for protection and commercialization of biotechnology IP
List criteria that are used to make decisions about biotechnology IP protection and management strategies and apply those criteria to make decisions
Deconstruct and analyse complex disputes in the field of biotechnology IP
List the important parts of a biotechnology patent
Demonstrate an awareness of the different interpretations of prior art in different countries in relation to biotechnology IP
Examine and evaluate trade secret litigation in biotechnology

assessments.assessment_title: Examination of a trade secret litigation case
assessments.task_description:
You will be provided with the headlines of a case involving theft of trade secrets. Prepare an essay style answer 1200 words (plus minus 10%) covering the following points.

  1. Identify the relevant court documents and case summary.
  2. Summarize the facts of the case.
  3. How was the breach identified?
  4. Identify the law(s) which have been alleged to have been breached.
  5. Summarize the courts ruling and the penalty imposed.
  6. Comment on the relevance of the penalty and anything the company could have done to prevent or mitigate the damage.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) in assessment

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: Submit your assignment through the course Turnitin submission point in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Deconstruction and analysis of a dispute
assessments.task_description:
1) Consider the Neemix patents held by W.R.Grace.

2) Download the relevant US and European patents (see blackboard website for more information). There are several patents in the family.

3) Consider the examiners report. Note briefly whether any prior art was cited against the patents.

4) List the prior art that was cited.

5) Briefly discuss the legal proceedings in the European Patent courts.

6) Briefly discuss the reasons for the finding by the European patent courts.

7) Briefly discuss the implications of this case and the lessons to be taken in relation to the interpretation of patent examiners’ search reports.

8) Discuss the different definitions of prior art in the US, Europe and Australia in relation to this case.

9) Briefly discuss the implications for IP management strategies.

Maximum 5 A4 pages, 1.5 spacing 12 pt font excluding references

NOTE: AFTER discussion with the course coordinator, another suitable dispute, chosen by the student in consultation with the course coordinator, may be used as the subject of this assessment item.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) in assessment

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.

assessments.assessment_title: Myriad decisions in the U.S. and Australia
assessments.task_description:
Students will write a maximum of 5 A4 pages, excluding references (1.5 spaced) analysing and explaining the differences between the decisions of the US Supreme Court of the United States in Association for Molecular Pathology versus Myriad Genetics, Inc. (2013), and the High Court of Australia in D'Arcy v Myriad Genetics Inc.(2015). Please refer to the marking criterion sheet for detailed guidelines.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) in assessment

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.

assessments.task_description:
The correct choice of IP protection strategy(s) depends on multiple factors.

Patenting is only one strategy and sometimes is not the best strategy for protecting and facilitating the subsequent management of biotechnology IP. Even when patenting is used, it may be used in conjunction with other IP protection strategies. You should have read about the variety of strategies available (in the case study on commercialisation of Bt cotton, for example) or heard about them in lectures. You will also have encountered the criteria that should be applied when deciding on IP protection strategies.

Your task:

Two biotechnology inventions/technologies will be distributed randomly to each student.

You will:

a) carry out in-depth research on each of the inventions/technologies in order to understand factors such as its novelty, complexity, reverse engineerability, intended user, and the part of the technology in an overall business strategy. You will need to consult patent databases and scientific literature and perhaps the literature describing strategies already in use by companies commercialising similar technologies.

You must

b) design and describe an IP protection strategy for each of the inventions/technologies and

c) write a detailed justification of the choice of method(s) of IP protection that are part of the strategy.

In general there will be more than one justification and more than one strategy for each technology. You may even decide to place a technology in the public domain in some special circumstances (which you must describe). References must be given for all sources of information.

You will then be required to present a 'client briefing' to discuss your conclusions and questions the client (examiners) may have.

Report length guideline: Maximum 8 A4 pages, 12 pt font, 1.5 spaced, per invention excluding references section.

Presentation length guideline: Maximum 5 min presentation with 10 min questions.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) in assessment

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Regular consultation with lecturer

Regular group consultations with course lecturer and other members of class, to discuss progress with assignment tasks. These consultation sessions, will be arranged in week one of the course. Topics covered will include:
Advanced trade secrets; Origin of IP; Case Studies; IP Case Law; Obviousness; Strategies for IP Management

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
